About

I’m a third-year PhD student in the Climate-Ocean-Atmosphere Program at Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego. You can find more about me by reading my welcome blog post who am I? what am I doing here?. You can find more about my work by reading my research statement or checking my publication list.

Blog

15 Nov 2015 . about-me . Who am I? What am I doing here? Comments

Hi there. I’m Cesar B. Rocha. I’m a world citizen, human-being with his ambitions, virtues and limitations. I was brought up to a middle class family and grew up in Sao Paulo, Brazil. My heritage speaks to the Brazilian diversity: I’m a mix up of Portuguese, Austriac, and Japanese people. Yes, I’m 25% Japanese: my grandmother’s family fled Japan in the 1930’s. My most lively childhood memories are of long hours of swim practice and of swimming competitions across Sao…

Career

  • Summer 2015

    Fellow of the Geophysical Fluids Dynamics Program

  • September 2013

    Started coding in Python and using version control

  • September 2013 - Today

    Joined the Climate-Ocean-Atmosphere Program at Scripps, UC San Diego

  • July 2013

    Graduated with a MSc degree from University of Sao Paulo

  • February 2011

    Graduated with a BSc degree from University of Sao Paulo

Code

I strive to produce high quality, well-tested code. I’m an advocate of free software. All my codes are under version control. I contribute to open source projects, and I’m core developer for pyqg. Checkout my repositories on github, and ping me if you have any questions.

I’m a member of NumFOCUS (open code, better science), I agree with Lorena Barba, and I endorse the science code manifesto.

Collaborators

I’m foturnate to work with very talented scientists. In the last couple of years, I have actively worked with

Bill Young, Sarah Gille, Teri Chereskin, Ian Grooms, Dimitris Menemenlis, Greg Chini

Contact

Feel free to ping me if you have any questions, ideas, or complaints.

Publications

Coming up soon

  • Rocha, C. B., W. R. Young, and I. Grooms: On Galerkin approximations for the surface-active quasigeostrophic equations, JPO doi:10.1175/JPO- D-15-0073.1, in press. (preprint, arXiv, codes, algebra details, wordle)

  • Rocha, C. B., T. Chereskin, S. T. Gille, and D. Menemenlis: “Mesoscale to submesoscale wavenumber spectra in Drake Passage, submitted to JPO. (preprint, data and codes)

  • T. Chereskin, S. T. Gille, Rocha, C. B., Cornuelle, B., and D. Menemenlis: “Wave-vortex decomposition in the California Current System, to be submitted to JPO.

  • Ardhuin, F., Rascle, N., Chapron, B., Gula, J., Molemaker, J., Gille, S., Menemenlis, D., Rocha, C.: Small scale currents have large effects on dominant ocean waves, to be submitted to GRL.

Printed

  • Rocha, C. B., I. C. A. da Silveira, B. M. Castro, and J. A. M. Lima (2014), Vertical structure, energetics, and dynamics of the Brazil Current System at 22S–28S, J. Geophys. Res. Oceans, 119, 52–69, doi:10.1002/2013JC009143

  • Rocha, C. B., A. Tandon, I. C. A. da Silveira, and J. A. M. Lima (2013), Traditional quasi-geostrophic modes and surface quasi-geostrophic solutions in the Southwestern Atlantic, J. Geophys. Res. Oceans, 118, 2734–2745. doi:10.1002/jgrc.20214
